#10
four alcoves off
the
center - in one of
which I am writing
near
the
sandbag-barricaded window.
The candles
threw a flickering
light
partially illuminating the room and
revealing the midnight
blue
posts
which
support a
ceiling decorated with gold medalioned filled
small
squares against a rich dark
red background with cross beams
covered with designs of red, green, blue and yellow.
square
room was taken up
by
The center of
a table around which we
Bond did not get back, so I
was
the only "barbarian"
were
seated.
present.
Thursday, November 11th,
Armistice Day - only in history.
This noon
cut loose at
the drone of many motors was audible but no planes in sight.
Mr. Peck and I left
the tiffin table and repaired
to a little open
near the roof.
Next to Mr.Peck's house,
large Chinese grave yard with lots of
mounds which provide
good shelter
against flying
shrapnel.
The nearby Chinese
ricksha coolies
and servants all
congregate
when an alarm
They come there
for the cover afforded by the hundreds of grave mounds
and also to be
near the American flag which they
at least
affords them some
measure of protection.
The noise of the motors became
presently out of
clouds to the south three Japanese twin-motored
bombers came into
view - below the clouds at
about
6000 feet.
The sky
was about 95 percent
at that altitude
holes showed a light
blue against the gray which
infrequent
course predominated.
The Three bombers
came directly at us,
then turned
away toward the
airport outside
the wall,
where no doubt more paper
planes had been
constructed by
those overworked kite-makers.
Machine guns tack-tack-
anti-aircraft guns banged from all quarters and the boom of
overhead kept us under a
protruding edge of the roof
shrapnel fell around us.
protective
a spent bit of
that drops
It's wise to
keep under
for the fragmentation is not always complete and
can give you quite a jolt if it is a large piece
The Three bombers in V
formation dropped their
airport and in the din of rapia explosions we coula see
clouds of dust
rising against the horizon some half mile away.
pursuit planes
followed and just messed around,
Three
one
of them stunting
while
the
other
two
stayed. more or less
in formation.
One of the
bombers left
formation and heading directly over the city.
Mr. Peck
opined that he
probably going to bomb the City inside the wall,
but instead he
again
flew directly over us,
and once more
headed for the
airport, possibly to check
the number of "planes"
destroyed.
As he flew over the city wall
an anti-aircraft shell burst
close to him
and we noted a bit of smoke come from the ship just as it
disappeared
some clouds.
Suddenly we
amazed to hear a lot of
shouts
and hand-clapping (a new form of
expressing approval among Chinese)
from the
grave-yard
and looking where they
were all excitedly gazing,
we saw 2
streak
of black smoke
then a blazing mass which broke into
two brightly
burning meteors which continued downward through five thousand
feet to hit,
still
in flames, near the airport.
The Japs had traded some
Nippon copy
of a Douglas all-metal
airplane with crew of six for a few
paper
ones!
Great rejoicing in Nanking but I guess it's a different
story
In six Tokyo homes! However, they died for "Charley"
and we'll let
him
worry about that!
Friday November 12th.
Another rainy day.
Trees sticking up into
celling.
Plan to leave tomorrow by boat from Hankow.
-10-
